SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: The pathogenic factors of BehÃ§et's disease (BD) differentiate according to geographical zones
The aim of this study was to evaluate the possible relation between this process and infection by type I herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) in Spain
METHODS: The prevalence of antibodies vs HSV-1 and cytomegalovirus (CMV) was studied by complement fixation in three series: A) 34 patients with BD; B) 21 with primary uveitis; C) 40 controls
HSV-1 specificity was established by ELISA
HLA typing was performed in 32 individuals from series A
RESULTS: The frequency of anti HSV-1 in A (76%) was greater (p = 0.045) than in C (55%) and B (66%)

These differences were more evident when titers equal/superior to 1/64 were considered as positive, with this being a value exceeding the 97.5% percentage of the control series (A = 21%, C = 2%, p = 0.015), specially for the ocular BD subgroup (26%, p = 0.011 with respect to C)
The B series did not differ from C (p = 0.88)
To the contrary no differences were observed in the distribution of titers vs CMV
Although a greater frequency of anti HSV-1 was observed in HLA-B51+ the differences were not significant (p = 0.09)
CONCLUSIONS: The frequency of evaluable titers of anti-HSV-1 is greater in patients with BD (specially with ocular involvement) than in the control series
No association was found between higher titers and HLA PB51+ phenotype
